loans.name: Ana

texts.es:
Doña Ana P. C. D. P., es casada, tiene 25 años D. edad, tiene 3 hijos y estan estudiando, se dedica a la produccion y confección D. faldas D. lona, lleva 10 años D. experiencia en este trabajo,  inició siendo operaria y quiere tener su negocio propio, cuenta con el apoyo D. su esposo quien la apoya en este trabajo.

AcuD. a ASDIR para solicitar préstamo que le servirá para comprar tela D. lona y una maquina para confeccionar las faldas, ya que quiere tener su negocio propio, y esta forma apoya a su familia a mejorar su candición D. vida.
texts.en:
Ana P. C. D. P. is 25 years old.  She has three children, and they go to school.

She makes canvas skirts.  She has ten years of experience in this work.  She started out being an employee, and she wants to have her own business.  Her husband is the one who helps her with this work.

She comes to ASDIR to request a loan to buy canvas fabric and a machine for making the skirts.  She wants to have her own business.  This is the way she will support her family and improve its living conditions.

loans.use: to buy canvas cloth and a sewing machine

loans.name: Sisanda Group

texts.en:
Tamsanqa, 42 years of age, is married with 3 children, aged between 6 and 20, two of whom attend school. She also takes care of two other relatives that live with her. In addition to her business, Tamsanqa has another source of income, the government’s child support grant.

Tamsanqa has been in business for 6 months, selling clothes and cold drinks at pay points in Mandini, South Africa. She has requested this loan through WDB and Kiva to buy clothes and cold drinks. The main challenge in her business is that customers buy on credit and fail to pay on time. In five years time, Tamsanqa would like to have a proper place for her business and have more employees. The extra income from this loan will help her pay for tertiary education for her children. In the photo, Tamsanqa is wearing a yellow top.

loans.use: to buy clothes and bags.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter, aged 44, is married to Consolata, who also does farming. They are blessed with four children, aged 18, 15, 12 and 9 years.

He does farming as well as livestock-rearing, which he has been doing for the last 40 years. The businesses earn him a monthly income of 30,000 Kenyan shillings.

This is his second loan from KADET LTD., and he has successfully managed to pay his previous loan. He will use the loan funds to buy bean seeds for planting and five bags of fertilizer.

Peter hopes to grow his businesses to become a large-scale farmer and improve his family's living standards.

loans.use: to buy bean seeds and five bags of fertilizer.

loans.name: Antokia Group

texts.en:
Nickodem, who is in his mid 20s, is unmarried.  He has been running a food market and catering businesses since 2009.  He works from 5:00am to around midnight daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be Nickodem's first loan from Kiva partner Tujijenge Tanzania.  He hopes for a loan to buy more food stock for his food market and catering business.

Nickodem will share this loan with his loan group "Antokia" which has a total of 16 members, who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: to buy more food stock for a food market and catering business.

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
Leonila is 52 years old and lives in the Philippines.  She is married with 2 children. 

Leonila has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks, noodles and detergents.  She has had this business for 5 years.  She requested a loan for PHP 4,000 to buy breads, snacks and canned goods.

Leonila is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Leonila hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy breads, snacks and canned goods

loans.name: Meshack

texts.en: Meshack is 26 years old and supports his parents in meeting some of their financial needs. Meshack has a bodaboda (motorcycle) transport business. He started this business a year ago. From it he gets a profit of KES. 4000 a month. Meshack has borrowed a loan of KES. 5000 from KADET Ltd with which he intends to buy sheep to raise, as he wants to diversify. He anticipates using the profits to expand his business. Meshack hopes to get married, build rental houses, and purchase a car for his transport business.

loans.use: To Purchase Sheep

loans.name: Kossi Gérard

texts.fr:
Kossi Gérard est un homme âgé(e) de 36ans. Il est marié å une revendeuse. Il a 02 enfants. 
Kossi Gérard travaille comme revendeur de boissons et d’alimentations générales depuis 2009. Il vend à toutes personnes à la devanture de sa maison. Il achète les produits à Lomé. Kossi Gérard a requis son premier cycle de prêt à  WAGES afin d’acheter des boissons, et des produits d’alimentation générale.
texts.en: Kossi Gérard is a 36-year-old man. He is married to a merchant and is the father of two children. He has been selling drinks and groceries since 2009. He sells to passers-by out of his home. He buys his merchandise in Lomé. Kossi Gérard came to the microfinance institution WAGES and applied for his first loan to buy drinks and groceries.

loans.use: to buy drinks and groceries.

loans.name: Nabeela's Group

texts.en:
Nabeela sells clothes and sweaters to financially support her husband. She is a very hard-working lady who tries to provide full support to her husband financially with her business. Her husband is an electrician by profession and offers electricA. repair services as well as sells electric items like tube lights and bulbs, etc. 

Nabeela has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband's business. With the loan, he will buy new electricA. repair tools & electric items to improve his business and provide better electricity services to his customers. Nabeela is hopeful that by providing the loan to her husband, he will be able to do his business better and increase his income. He is very experienced in his business and Nabeela has full confidence in him.
 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. With the previous loan, she established good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy electrical repair tools & electric items

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en: Loreta is 57 years old and lives in Aguada, Ozamis City with her husband and three children. She earns about PHP 10,000 a month by making and selling clothing, and is applying for a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy additional cloth to use to make items for her customers. She has been a member of PMPC for the last year.

loans.use: to buy additional cloth for a clothing-making business.

loans.name: Bashiran's Group

texts.en:
Bashiran is married and her husband is a hairdresser by profession. He is an expert in his work. His talent and good service help him to increase his clientele base in his community. He offers his services through his shop. Bashiran supports her husband by selling animals. She purchases young animals from the animal market, raises them and sells them to the butchers. Besides her business, she also carries out her responsibilities of a housewife very well. She is the mother of three daughters. All of them are illiterate and support her in her daily household responsibilities. 

Bashiran has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her animal sales business. With the loan, she will buy goats and sheep to raise and sell. She has been operating her business for some time now and is very confident that an investment will be a profitable one for her business.

loans.use: To buy goats and sheep to raise and sell

loans.name: Zurab

texts.en:
Zurab is a 43-year-old farmer from the village Klde, South Georgia. He is married and lives with his wife Mariam. The income source of the family is agriculture. In particular, they have milk cows, produce cheese and sell it on the local market. Also, Zurab and Mariam grow potatoes and maize on the plot. Harvested potatoes and maize are sold in Akhaltsikhe (nearby town) open market. Along with the above mentioned, Zurab often purchases calves, grows them and after couple of months sells them for a higher price. Total average monthly income of the family is 650 GEL. 

Zurab requested credit to purchase 4 calves. He will sell grown calves by December for a higher price. Zurab plans to reinvest the profit in the same business – purchase more calves. This loan will help the family to expand their agricultural business and increase the profit. It will have a positive impact on family living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase 4 calves for farm expansion

loans.name: Estrellita

texts.en:
Estrellita is 42 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 4 children. 
Estrellita has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for 7 years. She requested a loan of PHP 14,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages .
Estrellita has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Estrellita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Kymbat

texts.en:
Kymbat, 21, is a resident of Ananievo, a small village near to Isykul Lake in the north of Kyrgyzstan.  Two years ago, with an initial investment of 5,000 soms, she purchased eggs and began to resell them in another village.  At the moment she rents a café and works there together with her mom and older sister.  The monthly profit from this business is about 10,000 soms. With money received from the loan, Kymbat wants to purchase a sheep, flour and oil.  In the future she wishes to open her own café in Ananievo.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a sheep, flour and oil.

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta works hard to support her family. Violeta is single and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Violeta requested a loan of PHP 20,000 through NWTF to purchase more supplies to sell in her general store.

Violeta has been in this business for five years.

In the future, Violeta would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more supplies to sell in her general store

loans.name: Anitha

texts.en:
Anitha is 43 years old and married with one child who is 14 years old. Anitha owns a business selling cassava flour, cooking oil, vegetables, etc. This is her sixth successful year in this business and the hours of her business are from 7 am until 10 pm every day except on Saturday. She currently employs one person to help her. 

Anitha has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to increase her business by buying more cassava flour, vegetables, cooking oil, soap, and sugar to sell. With any profits, she will be able to build a secure future for her business as well as for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more cassava flour, cooking oil, soap, sugar, vegetables etc.

loans.name: Sango A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Sango A Group in Western Kenya! Francis is the facilitator of the Sango A group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Francis takes care of nine children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to have additional maize profits to educate his children, and to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the  2011 season, Francis had a very good maize yield harvesting 16 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Francis was only able to harvest 10 bags of maize on one acre of land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Francis and his group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Francis will educate his children and ensure food security for his family. 

In 2012, the members of Sango A group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize. 

He is pictured in the photograph with his group members.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Modesto

texts.en:
As a responsible father, Modesto aims to uplift his family's standard of living and give them a better life. He is 29 and has one infant child. He owns and manages a corn farming business in their village to generate income. He also operates motorcycle transport and hog-raising businesses to earn additional income. He plans to expand his corn plantation to increase his production in the coming harvest season.

He is asking for a loan of PHP 20,000 to buy seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides for his corn farming business. He mentioned that he can work out his plan to make a lot of improvements in the business with this additional capital. He hopes that his patience and hard work will bear a fruitful harvest in the coming season.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides for his corn farming business.

loans.name: Nadeem

texts.en:
Nadeem is a 22-year-old young man who has a fruit and vegetable store that is his only source of income. Nadeem wants to purchase fresh fruits and vegetables in bulk so that he has a better collection to sell. The amount of money he has isn't enough, so he needs a loan of $3,000 from Palestine for Credit & Development (FATEN). When Nadeem gets this loan he will purchase fruits and vegetables, which will provide him with a better and fresher collection to resell and increase his income so that he may live in better conditions. 

Nadeem is photographed in his store.

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables in bulk to resell.

loans.name: Jitegemee C Group

texts.en:
Greetings from the Jitegemee C Group in Western Kenya! Concepta is the facilitator of the Jitegemee C group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Concepta takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and to ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Concepta had a very good maize yield harvesting 18 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Concepta was only able to harvest eight bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Concepta and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs such as fertilizer and seed is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which also includes training, credit, and insurance. 

With the income from maize sales, Concepta will save for the future and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Jitegemee C group will each plant between one half and one acre of maize.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.en: Maria Luisa is a married woman having one child. Maria Luisa is 47 years old, residing in Misamis Occidental: Philippines. Maria Luisa owns and operates farmland, planting and harvesting rice for sale to earn a living and she's been in this business for 10 years. Each month, she earns 4,800 Philippines pesos (PHP) doing this type of business. She requested a loan of 35,000 PHP to purchase additional fertilizer. Maria Luisa has been a member of GDMPC for almost a year. In the future, Maria Luisa wants to make improvements of her house and to support the completion of her child's education.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase various materials for her sewing business.

loans.name: Santa Lucia Group

texts.es: Este grupos solidario se llama  Santa Lucia, está conformado por la señora Norma Edith va a comprar con su préstamo blusas, pantalones, suéter, chamarras, ropa interior, la señora Susana va a comprar tela, hilos, agujas, cierres, botones para confeccionar ropa, la señora Guillermina va a comprar  carteras, peines, aretes, pinzas, valerianas, etc., la señorita Dulce Yesica va a comprar zapatos y botas para su venta. La señora Guillermina tiene 46 años de edad, ella vive en unión libre, ellos tiene 4 hijos 3 mujeres y 1 varón, 2 de sus hijas están estudiando la pequeña en la primaria y otra estudia la academia para secretaria, ella vende artículos de adorno para dama y niñas, ella solicito su prestamo para comprar bolitas, diademas, barnices, lápiz labial, ligas, delineadores, peines, peinetas, aretes, enchinadores, maquillajes y dulces, ella inicio su negocio hace un año por convencimiento de su hija, ella tenía unos ahorros y con estos compro la mercancía, su negocio es importante porque le gusta vender y le va ayudando a la familia económicamente, ella se siente orgullosa de ver que su negocio va creciendo, ella está planeando ampliar su negocio meter regalos y juguetes y lo piensa lograr trabajando en su negocio y con el siguiente prestamo. Sus sueños y esperanza son tener su negocio mas grande y que sus hijas sigan esgudiando. Las integrantes del grupo quieren decirle a Kiva y a Fundacion Realidad "gracias por darnos la oportunidad de estos prestamos, para hacer realidad nuestros sueños y proyectos".
texts.en:
This cooperative group is called Santa Lucia and it's formed by: Norma Edith who is going to buy shirts, pants, sweaters, jackets, and underwear with her loan; Susana who is going to buy fabric, thread, needles, zippers, and buttons to make clothes; Guillermina who is going to buy wallets, combs, earrings, tweezers, and supplements; Dulce Yesica who is going to buy shoes and boots for sale.

Guillermina is 46 and lives with her common law partner, they have four children; three girls and one boy, two of her daughters are studying in elementary school and a bachelor, she sells accessories for women and girls, she requested a loan to buy headpieces, nail polish, lipstick, hair elastics, eyeliners, combs, brushes, earrings, hair rolls, makeup and candy, she started her business a year ago convinced by her daughter she had some savings to buy merchandise, her business is important to her because she likes to sell and help her family financially, she feels proud to see her business grow and plans to expand it and sell gifts and toys, she hopes to achieve this by working hard and with the next loan. Her dreams and hope are to have a big business and see her children continue their studies.  The members of this group want to say to Kiva and Fundacion Realidad: “thank you for giving us an opportunity with these loans, for making our dreams and projects come true”.

loans.use: to buy shirts, pants, sweaters, jackets, underwear, fabric, thread, needles, zippers, wallets, combs, earrings, tweezers, and supplements for sale.

loans.name: Judy

texts.en: Judy is hard working and an active member of Kahumbu Hannah Women’s Group. Judy is 32 years old, married and has two boys and one girl. Her husband is a fine artist and shares his income with the entire family. Judy started business with a grocery and later an electronics shop in 2000. She sells mobile phones and their accessories; electric cables, iron boxes, Radios, CDs and small CD players. She started with and initial capital of $440 and since then, the business has been growing and today it is worth $1,428. This has been possible because of the business skills and financial support she received with other group members from WEEC. The business takes care of all the necessities at home and school fees for the children. The use of mobile phones increases every day and so do the sales and income.

loans.use: Judy wants to buy mobile phones and accessories to fill the gap in her stock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock up goods and expand the business

loans.name: Olive

texts.en: Olive M. sells her pancakes at her house or even delivers them to the school. Olive works five days per week, and she can earn $100 a day. This is her source of income to support her family. The money she gets for the week is then used to buy other bags of flour and sugar for the next order. She is a good saver; this is how she finances her children’s school activities. She plans to use the loan to purchase more ingredients to make the pancakes.

loans.use: To purchase flour, sugar, baking powder, dripping

loans.name: Loeurng

texts.en: Loeurng has been married for 5 years to her second husband who is a farmer. She has 1 son and 4 daughters. She has been selling vegetables and meat for over 7 years. Three of her children are working in a factory, while the others are still studying or stay at home. Both Loeurng and her husband have little education, but they have a very good character. They will use the loan of US$300 to buy cement, bricks and other materials to repair their house, and to purchase more vegetables and meat for sale to expand the business. Loeurng will be able to repay the loan.

loans.use: (1) House repair - purchase of cement, bricks and other materials; (2) Purchase of more grocery items for sale

loans.name: Fortunata

texts.en:
Fortunata C., Elisa Pariona, Sonia Quispe, and Hilda Ccorahua belong to a village bank called “Ccatarisun” which is a quechua (native language) word that means “Dawn”. As part of the village bank, the four of them receive a loan together and the responsibility for repayment is on all four women. They are asking a total loan of US$ 1200. Fortunata will use her share to buy more ingredients to prepare her "moliente".

In the midst of a bustling street market in Ayacucho, Peru, Fortunata can be found every day behind her cart selling “moliente,” hot herbal beverages. In addition to herbs and teas, she also has a small supply of homeopathic remedies. Her most popular product is a blend of “sábila,” a type of cactus leaves that she cuts open and then scrapes out the insides. She adds honey, and a variety of herbal teas. She tops this mixture off with a little hot water, and stirs well. It helps with digestion and is good for the immune system.

This drink as well as many others are very popular, and are sold for 1 Nuevo Sol (or about $0.30 U.S.) Fortunata's customers speak both Quechua, the indigenous language of Peru, and Spanish. Many are regulars, who come to Fortunata’s cart every day. Although hesitant to have her picture taken, Fortunata is a friendly woman who always engages her clients in conversation; they talk about her plants, market gossip, or their family lives.

Fortunata begins each day at 4:30 AM, in order to set up her stand by 5. She caters to a steady stream of customers until 9 a.m., before returning home to care for her four small children. She occasionally has time for a nap before returning to sell beverages, although a different variety, from 8 PM to midnight. Her husband helps out with the children when she is operating the cart, as well as helping prepare the plants she uses for tea each day before work.

Fortunata, Elisa, Sonia, and Hilda are looking forward to receiving this loan of US$1200, to be distributed among the four of them.

loans.use: buy more ingredients to prepare her "moliente"

loans.name: Foday

texts.en: Foday is 36 years old and married with 3 children.  He has been with Salone Microfinance Trust since 2004. With his previous loans, he diversified his business.  He is presently engaged in the selling and renting of music and film CDs, as well as selling engine oil, kerosene and fuel, in the market of Kabala town in Sierra Leone.  Foday is serious about expanding his inventory and would like a loan of $1200 to do so.

loans.use: Expansion of his stock of items for sale

loans.name: I Made Lotro

texts.id:
I Made Lotro is a gentlemen with high family dedication. His hard work is solely done for the well being of his wife and two school aged children. To fulfill his obligation, I Made Lotro opens a kiosk at his house. Although the kiosk is still small since his capital is limited, but his persistance made his business really well, and could provide enough for family needs. With a capital of Rp1,000,000 (about US$110), I Made Lotro could make profit of about Rp30,000 (about US$3.30) each day. From every profit he made, I Made Lotro also save a little to be used to expand other business of raising pigs, specifically mother pig that is done by his wife. So I Made Lotro is not by himself in obtaining family income, but also teaches his wife to take part in family well being. From Dinari's loan, I Made Lotro hopes that his kiosk business could be expanded, by adding variation to his sales, which initally consisted of light food, so that he could also sell other daily needs items.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

I Made Lotro seorang pria yang berdedikasi tinggi terhadap keluarganya. Kerja kerasnya selama ini semata-mata dilakukannya untuk mengusahakan kesejahteraan istri dan dua orang anaknya yang masih bersekolah. Untuk memenuhi kewajibannya ini I Made Lotro membuka usaha warung di rumahnya. Walaupun warungnya masih kecil karena modal yang dimilikinya terbatas tetapi keuletannya membuat usahanya ini benar-benar bermanfaat dan mendatangkan hasil yang cukup untuk memenuhi kebutuhan keluarganya. Dengan modal Rp. 1.000.000,- I Made Lotro bisa mendapat keuntungan sekitar Rp. 30.000,- per hari. Dari setiap keuntungan yang diperolehnya itu I Made Lotro juga menyisihkan sebagian kecil untuk di simpan dan kemudian dipakainya untuk mengembangkan usaha yang lain yaitu memelihara ternak babi khususnya babi penginduk yang dikelola oleh istrinya. Jadi I Made Lotro tidak hanya berusaha sendirian dalam mengelola keuangan rumah tangganya, tetapi juga mengajarkan istrinya untuk ambil bagian dalm mengusahakan kesejahteraan keluarga mereka. Dengan memperoleh pinjaman modal usaha dari DINARI I Made Lotro berharap usaha warungnya bisa dikembangkan dengan menambah variasi dagangannya yang semula hanya menjual makanan ringan saja, agar bisa menjual segala macam kebutuhan sehari-hari

loans.use:
To buy sales items for kiosk

Membeli barang dagangan untuk melengkapi warungnya

loans.name: Irene

texts.es:
Unfortunately, Irene's mother suffered an embolism and can no longer manage by herself. The money her husband earns isn't enough to pay for all of the family's expenses and Irene's mother's medications. This is why Irene decided to start a business that didn't take up a lot of her time to be able to take care of her mother. She started to buy shoes to resell among her friends and neighbors.

However, she doesn't have enough supplies of winter shoes right now to be able to offer her clients. This is why she is requesting a loan of $300 that she is willing to repay in 4 months. With this money, Irene will be able to buy shoes to have a better assortment. With your help, Irene will be able to make enough money to pay for her mother's medications.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Lamentablemente la madre de Irene sufrió una Embolia y ya no puede valerse por sí sola. Y lo que gana el esposo de Irene no alcanza para los gastos de la familia y las medicinas de la mamá de Irene. Es por eso que Irene decidió comenzar un negocio que no le quite mucho tiempo y le deje ganancias para poder atender a su mamá. Es por eso que comenzó a comprar zapatos para revenderlo entre sus amigos y vecinos.

Sin embargo actualmente no cuenta con mucho surtido de invierno como para ofrecerle a sus clientes es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $300 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 4 meses y con este dinero Irene podrá comprar más zapatos para tener un mejor surtido. Con tu ayuda Irene podrá sacar dinero para poder pagar las medicinas de su mamá.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal merchadise

loans.name: Juana Bacilia

texts.es:
Juana Bacilia is 48 years old, and completed her studies only to the fifth grade. She currently lives in the La Libertad section of the province of Otuzco. She has three children who are all grown and no longer depend on her financially.

She started her business at a very young age, first helping her mother and later on her own. She first had a small store, but she quit this endeavor after she was robbed and because the community is quite small and had other similar establishments. Today, she instead buys and sells cereals/grains which she buys from various producers and then takes to Trujillo to sell. In addition, she buys curd with which to make cheeses to also sell in Trujillo.

Juana is a founding member of the collective bank “Mujeres de Trabajo” (“Working Women”), where she obtained her first loan of 300 soles (Peruvian currency). She used the funds to buy groceries to stock her store. With the loan of 2,300 soles (approximately $800USD), to be repaid in four months, she will buy cereals at good prices and also the curd to make cheeses from.

Juana dreams of having a small truck to use for transporting her goods to Trujillo.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Juana Bacilia tiene 48 años de edad, estudió sólo hasta quinto grado de primaria y actualmente vive en el Centro Poblado Menor Piscopampa, distrito de Mache, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad. Juana tiene tres hijos, pero todos mayores de edad y que ya no dependen de ella. Empezó su negocio desde muy joven, primero ayudando a su madre y luego con un dinero que recibió como apoyo inició sola su actividad. Primero tuvo una pequeña bodega en su comunidad, pero luego la dejó debido a que le robaron y también porque el poblado no es muy grande y hay otros negocios similares. Ahora se dedica a la compra y venta de cereales; los compra a pequeños productores de diferentes caseríos y luego los lleva a vender a la ciudad de Trujillo, además también compra cuajada para preparar quesos y también llevarlos a vender a Trujillo. La señora Juana es socia fundadora del banco comunal “Mujeres de Trabajo” lugar donde obtuvo un primer préstamo de S/.300, con los que compró abarrotes para implementar su bodega que en ese entonces tenía. Con el préstamo de S/.2,300, el cual pagará en 4 meses comprará cereales a buen precio y también cuajada para preparar los quesos. La señora Juana sueña con tener un camioncito para trasladar la mercadería hasta Trujillo.

loans.use: Purchase cereals, as well as ingredients to make cheese.

loans.name: Binta

texts.en: Binta sells childrens clothes, shoes, lotions, and gels.  Due to a lack of space in the market, she established her business outside the veranda of her friend’s grocery shop but finds it difficult to remain during the rainy season.  With the previous loans, Binta diversified the business, and now, she would like to find appropriate shelter for rent in the market town of Makeni in Sierra Leone.  She is therefore requesting a loan of $525 to increase her stock for more profit, which will enable her to earn enough profits to rent a place for running the business.  Binta is 38 years old and married with 3 children.

loans.use: Binta needs to increase her stock so that her profits will be large enough to enable her to rent space for her business.

loans.name: Maila's Changamoto Group

texts.en:
Maila is 23 years old and is married with one child, age 1 year old. Maila has been selling clothes since 2007. She works every day from 7.30 am to 6 pm at her business, and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Maria, who also has a business of selling clothes.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Kheng

texts.en: Kheng C. is a 35-year-old widow with one child. She lives in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, where she earns around $1.50 a day working in a garment factory. To increase her income, she has applied for a loan from Kiva to rent a plot of land on which to grow beans, and to buy the seeds she needs to start her new business.

loans.use: To rent land on which to grow beans and to buy seeds.

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.es:
I make a living by cutting hair. I have done this for 3 years, and I have identified myself with my clients by giving them excellent service. I need this credit to buy two hair clippers. I also need to buy two revolving chairs: one for children, and one for adults.

This business has gone well for me, thank God. With it, I help my family with their education, health, and clothing. My vision is to have another barber shop and to be able to expand my business.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Me dedíco al servicio de corte de cabello, llevo 3 años en el atendiendo; me he identificado con mis clientes en darles un excelente servicio; éste crédito lo necesito para comprar dos maquinas rasuradoras de cabello. Además necesito comprar dos sillas giratorias una para niño y otra para adulto.

En el negocio gracias a Dios me ha ido bien, con ésto ayudo a mi familia en lo que se refiere a estudios, salud, vestuario. Mi visión es poder tener otra barbería y poder así expandirme en mi negocio.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for his barber shop

loans.name: Teo Mbatudde's Group

texts.en:
Teo M. is a tailor who enjoys wearing her designs. She is a married woman with 6 children, the youngest being 6 and the oldest 18, all of whom are in school. Teo has been operating her shop for 7 years and finds business to be fair.

In order to make clothes for both men and women, Teo rides a matatu (a shared van) into Kampala to buy textiles and then returns to the store she rents to do the tailoring. She serves an average of 5 customers a day and with the revenues from the tailor shop has been able to open a bar in which she sells beer and soda.

Teo got her first loan from MCDT 4 years ago and has successfully paid back 8 loans. By working with MCDT, she has been able to sell more clothes because she can get more materials to serve more customers. In addition, she has expanded to making uniforms for a local elementary school, The Red Star School. This success has not come without difficulties, as some people do not pay on time for the clothes she has made or sometimes do not pay at all, making it difficult to predict and rely on a steady cash flow.

Due to the proceeds she has garnered thus far, Teo has been able to sustain her family and send all her children to school. With this loan, she hopes to get a step closer to her future goals of expanding her businesses and buying a new plot of land for her house.

The other members of the group are Ruth N., who sells old clothes; Hamida N., who owns and runs a salon; Robina Nabosa, who sells charcoal; and Miriam M., who sells raw food.

loans.use: To stock more materials to make clothes

loans.name: Juan Antonio

texts.es:
Juan Antonio began his career working for a newspaper for a period of five years, after which he took the initiative to start his own business since he was receiving a very low salary at the paper and he had a desire to improve his life. Since he had experience in the business, he began his own printing company and little by little he began to earn a good income and things have generally gone well for him.

Juan Antonio is asking for a loan of US $800, which he will repay in six months, to purchase supplies. With your assistance he will be able to increase his business opportunities.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer Ann Kenney Molloy

Juan Antonio empezó laborando en un periódico por un periodo de 5 años, pero posteriormente tuvo la iniciativa de iniciar su propio negocio, por que recibía un salario muy bajo y pues el quería superarse día con día, como el ya tenía conocimiento del mismo, puso su negocio de impresiones y poco a poco le fue dando buenos ingresos y le ha ido bien,

El solicita de un crédito por US $ 800 que pagara en 6 meses, para la compra de material. Con tu apoyo el hara crecer su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase supplies

loans.name: Yoem

texts.en: Mrs. Yoem S. lives in Boeng Krum Kraom Village in Kandal Province. She and her husband, Mr. Prum Bonh, are farmers. Aside from this business, Mr. Prum Bonh is rice wine maker and pig breeder in the local village. Since his business activities are going well, he wants to expand them. So Mrs. Yoem S. decided to ask for a loan to buy ten piglets for $250, and she would use the other part of the loan to purchase more rice to make wine. Mrs. Yoem S. is 39 years old and the mother of six children, one of whom is a farmer while other two are employed in a garment factory. The other two are attending school, while the youngest one is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy ten piglets and more rice to make rice wine.

loans.name: Woda

texts.fr: Née en 1973 à Agoè Atsanvé, Woda W. est mariée et a trois (03)  enfants à charge. Elle est commerçante et vend des sacs de charbon de bois et des sacs de maïs. Elle sollicite ce crédit dans le soucis de développer son commerce et de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Born in 1973 in Agoè Atsanvé, Woda W. is married and has three children in her care. She is a merchant and sells sacks of charcoal and sacks of corn. She is requesting this loan with the concern of developing her business and to provide for her family's needs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell charcoal and corn

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To invest in women's pants in order to move her small business forward.

loans.name: Nueva Generación Group

texts.es: El grupo Nueva Generación esta representado por la señora Margarita, existen algunos parentescos familiares entre las socias pero cada una posee su propia fuente de ingreso independiente, en su mayoría los socios se dedican a la venta de comida y diferentes comestibles como víveres y verduras, entre los varones tiene actividades como la venta de automóviles o a la reparación de los mismos, son gente trabajadora con experiencia en sus diferentes rubros y con ganas de progresar. En lo que se refiere a experiencia en el trabajo con grupos solidarios ellos llevan cumpliendo su segundo ciclo con el mismo grupo y con algunos integrantes nuevos. Referente al destino del financiamiento será para el incremento de insumos para la venta y a la compra de materiales de trabajo para incrementar sus ingresos y mejor su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
The group "Nueva Generación" (New Generation) is represented by Mrs. Margarita. Some of the members are related through family but each has her own income. The majority of members sell foodstuffs and various items such as food provision and vegetables. The men in the group work in areas such as selling cars and repairing same. These are hardworking folks with experience in their businesses and a desire to prosper. They are experienced working with solidarity groups as this is their second cycle with this same group and they've added a few new members. As for the financing, it is targeted for acquiring raw materials for buying/selling in the workplace in order to increase their profits and improve their quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Pamela Carreón, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital de Operaciones

loans.name: Deyci

texts.es: Deicy tiene 33 años, es casada, tiene un hijo, viven en una casa alquilada. Ante de de casarse, junto a su madre se dedicaban a la compra y venta de fruta, al por mayor y menor, pero desde hace 6 años está trabajando en la municipalidad de su localidad, entonces de lunes a viernes su madre está a cargo del negocio, y los sábados y domingos venden juntas, además todas las noches, ambas hacen el balance respectivo de sus ventas. Deyci es una mujer de negocio, por lo que considera tener varios ingresos económicos en diferentes conceptos, es por ello, que a pesar de que ahora tiene un trabajo estable, no deja la venta de fruta, porque es muy rentable, ya que en el pasado se sostenía solo de esas ganancias. Lo que lamenta es que sabe que no puede cargar a su madre con toda la responsabilidad, porque hay días que la nota muy cansada, ya que no tiene las mismas fuerzas que cuando era más joven. Es su 5to préstamo con Microfinanzas Prisma, y paga muy puntual sus cuotas. El dinero solicitado le servirá para incrementar y almacenarse de frutas, así podrá enviar una buena cantidad para venderse en la ciudad de Lima, donde ganará mucho más.
texts.en:
Deyci is 33 yars old, married, has a son, and lives in a rented house. Since before she was married she has been buying and selling fruit at wholesale and retail with her mother. For the past 6 years she has been working in the municipality of her area, so Monday through Friday her mother is in charge of the business and on Saturdays and Sundays they sell together. Additionally, every night they both do the accounting for their sales. Deyci is a business woman who has various sources of income from different businesses. In spite of having a stable job she has not stopped selling fruit because it is very profitable, and in the past she was able to support herself solely from these earnings. She knows that she cannot ask her mother to be fully responsible for the business because there are days that she sees her mother is very tired because she doesn’t have the same energy today as when she was younger. This is her 5th loan with Microfinanzas Prisma, and she is punctual with her payments. The money will be used to increase and stock fruit so that she will be able to send a good quantity to sell in Lima city, where she will earn much more money.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fruits to increase her stock of fruit

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity D. is a fashion designer and she also sells sarongs. She is 36 years old and married with 2 children. Charity requests a loan in the amount of N80, 000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all who have made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Zenon

texts.es:
Zenon vive en la calle “ K ” # 100   de la zona Puerto Mejillones en la ciudad de El Alto.
 
Vive junto a su esposa  y  sus  cinco hijos que van desde los catorce a los tres meses de edad, en su domicilio propio.
 
Trabaja como chofer asalariado de transporte pesado a larga distancia con la republica del Perú, su esposa se dedica a la confección de cubrecamas artesanalmente.
 
El crédito lo destinará en la adquisición de materiales  para la construcción de un techo en el cual actualmente funciona su cocina y habilitarlo para la habitación de uno de sus hijos y mejorar sus condiciones de vida. 
 
Es el primer   crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada lo califica para otorgarle el crédito.
texts.en:
Zenon lives at 100 “K” street, in the region of Puerto Mejillones en the city of El Alto. He lives together with his wife and his five children who range from the age of 14 to 3 months, in his own house. He works as a salary-paid chauffer, tedious from the large distances of Peru. His wife works as an artisan, making bedspreads. This loan will be used for the acquisition of materials for construction of a roof for a room that will double as a functioning kitchen and a bedroom for one of his sons, and to better his living conditions. This is his first loan with Impro, but his completed evaluation warrants granting him the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Matt Capetola, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The construction of a roof over his kitchen that will double as a bedroom for his son.

loans.name: Vali

texts.ru: Дадоев Вали 1963 года рождения, имеет 3 детей, жена домохозяйка. Вали работает стоматологом в городской стоматологической клинике более 15 лет, лечит зубы и устанавливает протезы. В этом году он планирует выдать замуж одну из дочерей. Дочь студентка и к ней  сватаются много молодых парней. Ему потребуется необходимая сумма что бы докупить  приданное и провести некоторые мероприятия. Он хороший врач и унего много пациентов, но из-за отсутствии электричества потребность его услуги снизилась. Он также работает в одной из частной клиники, где есть  электричество , и он может проводить свои операции. Погашать он планирует от сдельной работы своих услуг. Он благодарен Микроинвест и кредит от КИВА. В дальнейшем планирует получить кредит на открытие своего частного дела.
texts.en:
Vali D. -- born in 1963, married, has 3 children. His wife is a homemaker. Vali is a dentist with 15 years of experience working at the local dental clinic. This year, Vali plans to celebrate a wedding for one of his daughters. His daughter is a college student and many young men wish to marry her. Vali needs this loan to provide for a proper dowry and pay for the wedding party. Vali D. is a good doctor and has many loyal patients. Unfortunately, due to frequent interruptions of electric power in the local clinic, Vali's workload there decreased. As an alternative, Vali D. is working at a private clinic where he can work without interruption. Vali thanks all Kiva lenders for their generosity and hopes to apply for another Kiva loan soon to finance opening of a private practice.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For weddings

loans.name: Juana Antonia

texts.es:
En el municipio de Ciudad Sandino de la ciudad de Managua, la señora Juana G. posee su propio negocio de pulpería el cual atiende a diario con el propósito de beneficiar a su familia brindándole las condiciones de vida necesarias.

Es de importancia destacar que ella ha sido una persona muy trabajadora y hoy en día el problema que atraviesa es que se le agotan sus productos y para ello acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con un crédito para la compra de los productos y así continuar en su negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Juana G. has her own mini market. It is located in the Ciudad Sandino municipality in the city of Managua. She works there every day to help her family and provide them with life’s necessities.

It is important to point out that she has been a very hard worker. The problem that she now comes across is that she runs out of her products. This is why she comes to Ceprodel. She would like a loan to buy products and continue her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en: Joshua A. is 38 years old and married with three children.  He sells electronics.  Joshua is requesting a N100,000 loan to purchase more electronics to sell.  He says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more electronics to sell.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana Y. is fifty-nine years old. She is widowed and has given birth to four children, one son and three daughters. She says all of her children are out of school and working. Juliana says she lives with her sisters in a family house in a farming/commercial town called Achiase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana.

She is a trader. She trades in second-hand textiles – clothes for both sexes and also bed sheets. She procures bales of textiles from Accra and sells in her community by hawking. She says she also treks to other towns to sell on their market days.

Juliana has been in business for two years and desires to expand her business. She is hoping to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To procure second hand textiles

loans.name: Komlanvi

texts.fr: Ce monsieur exerce comme activité le commerce de gravier, il est marié et père de 02 enfants. C’est avec le surplus de revenu de son commerce qu’il subvient aux charges du foyer, il fait ce commerce depuis 2003. Il a reçu une commande d’un de ses clients qu’il ne peut satisfaire car ne disposant pas de moyens, il sollicite alors de WAGES son premier crédit pour convoyer 1 camion de 25 mètre cube de gravier.
texts.en:
This gentleman has a business selling gravel. He is married and the father of 2 children. The profit from his little business allows him to support his household. He has been in this business since 2003. He has received an order from one of his customers that he cannot fill because he lacks working capital, so he has asked WAGES for his first loan to be able to deliver 1 truckload of 25 cubic meters of gravel.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of gravel for re-sale

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.fr: Y. Jeanne est née le 26 Mars 1973 à Adjohoun un petit village du Département de l’OUEME dont elle est originaire. Jeanne est mariée à ABLO Bienvenu ; et Jeanne est  mère de trois enfants dont un garçon et deux filles tous scolarisés. Jeanne vit avec sa famille vit à AGBODJEDO, un quartier de Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Jeanne vend à domicile de bois de chauffage, de charbon de bois et du maïs en détail. C’est dans les marchés locaux en dehors de la ville de COTONOU que Jeanne s’approvisionne en ces différents produits. C’est le mari de Jeanne qui supporte les charges familiales ; ainsi, Jeanne arrive à mieux développer son activité en y investissant ses revenus. Jeanne a déjà eu trois crédits de ALIDé ; crédits qu’elle a très bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu amener son activité à un stade supérieur. Aujourd’hui encore Jeanne sollicite un quatrième crédit de ALIDé pour augmenter le volume de son activité afin de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle sans cesse croissante.
texts.en:
Y. Jeanne was born on March 26, 1973 in Adjohoun, a small village in OUEME County, to where she traces her roots. She is the mother of three children, a boy and two girls who are all in school. She lives with her family in AGBODJEDO, a district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Jeanne used to sell firewood, charcoal, and corn retail out of her house. The local marketplaces outside the the city of Cotonou is where she stock up with these different goods. Her husband covers family expenses, so she is managing to improve her business by investing her revenues into it. Jeanne has already had three ALIDÉ loans and has indeed repaid them, having used them to raise her business to a higher level. Again now, she's requesting a fourth loan from ALIDÉ to increase her business volume in order to respond better to the demands of her customers, who are continuously increasing.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a truck-load of firewood, six sacks of charcoal, and two 50-kg sacks of corn

loans.name: Ablavi

texts.fr: Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de boissons locales alcoolisées appelé "sodabi" , elle fait ce commerce depuis 1994 ce qui lui a donné une parfaite maîtrise de ce commerce. elle fait face actuellement à une rupture de stock c’est pour cela qu’elle s’adresse à WAGES pour solliciter son premier crédit pour acheter  10 bidons de 25 litres de sodabi.
texts.en:
This lady sells a locally-made alcoholic beverage called "sodabi". She has been running this business since 1994 so she is very good at it. She presently is experiencing difficulty keeping her stock up, so she has come to WAGES to request her first loan to buy 10 jerry cans of 25 liters of "sodabi".

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing a locally made alcoholic beverage for resale

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.en: Charlotte O. is a fifty-four-year-old petty trader who is hard-working and enterprising. She is married with seven children who are all currently in school. She has been selling foodstuffs like maize, plantains, beans, groundnuts and gari (manioc couscous) in the neighborhood to her loyal customers. She sells on a table top at the local market and treks to other towns to sell on their market days. She has been in business for some years now. She says selling these products is very lucrative and therefore she wants to expand her inventory to enable her to make good income to rent a room for a store.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs for resale

loans.name: Madina

texts.en: K. Madina is married with a small daughter and a son. Madina’s store, which sells kid’s clothing, is located at one of the busiest city markets. She has been in this business for three years. Madina is a serious and prudent business owner. Her perseverance, together with lending services from “IMON International”, has enabled her to gradually expand her business. There are many vendors and competition in clothing sales is high. However, Madina’s pleasant manner and willingness to meet clients’ needs have helped her to keep a loyal clientele. Madina is requesting a loan of 4,000 Somoni to purchase an assortment of clothing items in bulk. Her responsibility, stable business growth, and prompt payment record characterize Madina as a consistent and serious entrepreneur capable of loan repayment. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new clothing in bulk

loans.name: Lesbia Mayerly

texts.es: La señora Lesbia tiene la edad de 28 años, reside en el bario Laureles Norte en la capital de Managua, casada su esposo trabaja como docente de primaria y es técnico en refrigeración, cual trabaja junto con su esposa, lleva cinco años, inicio con recursos de su salario, tiene tres hijos de 4,9 y 11 años de edad, su meta es poder construir su propia casa, con este crédito va ha legalizar su negocio y así poder tener personería jurídica el cual lograra tener mejor solidez al ofertar sus servicios. Da las gracias ala institución por los beneficios adquirido para su familia y su negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Lesbia is 28 years old. She lives in the town of Laureles Norte, in the capital of Managua. She is married and her husband works as a grammar school teacher and a refrigeration technician, as well as, alongside his wife of five years. She has three children who are 4, 9 and 11 years old. Her goal is to be able to build her own house. With this loan she will obtain legal services to legitimize her business, as well as, to create a more solid enterprise. She is grateful to the institution for the benefits provided to her family and business.

Translated from Spanish by Veronica Martino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to legitimize her business in order to guarantee the services of her business

loans.name: Susana Filomena

texts.es: Susana Filomena E. tiene 53 años y 3 hijos que trabajan de manera independiente. Ella es una persona que siempre le ha gustado salir adelante. Hace más de 10 años que se dedica a esta actividad económica como es la venta de comida. Además como madre responsable por lo que sus 3 tenían que comer y estudiar, Susana realizo muchos sacrificios ya que cocinaba una gran cantidad de comida y no tenía a nadie que le ayudara con esto por lo que pero al notar que obtenía muy buenos ingresos decide seguir invirtiendo en capital de trabajo. Es por eso que solicita este financiamiento para la compra de arroz, aceite, frijoles, carne y frutas. Su mayor sueño es poseer un restaurante para seguir ayudando a su familia.

loans.use: capital de trabajo

loans.name: Danelda

texts.en:
Danelda B. has been a member of Kiva partner, ASHI, for a year. When she became a member, she accessed a loan that she used to finance a food vending business she manages herself, and a rice farming business managed by her farm laborer husband. After paying off the first loan from ASHI in six months, Danelda is now requesting a much larger loan that she will use to finance her husband’s fishing business. She wants to purchase a fishing boat for her husband and start up a hog-fattening (pig-raising) business.

Aside from rice farming and food vending, Danelda’s husband’s fishing business has been a large source of the family’s daily income and has enabled Danelda to save for her weekly payment to ASHI. Nevertheless, a hog-fattening business could also enrich their income since this business can yield as much as double the amount of its capital in profit once the hog is sold live, or slaughtered and sold per kilo, after every four months of fattening.

Danelda has to have many sources of income because she has seven children to nurture and support. These children range in age from 7 to 23 years old. Five of her eldest children have stopped studying because of the family's very poor financial situation. With loans from ASHI, Danelda wants to grow sources of income to meet the needs of her children and enable them to go back to school.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing boat, and finance a pig raising business

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina, who is married, runs a small business selling children’s clothing in the central marketplace of her home town of Vinogradovo. In business now for four years, she has 35,000 Grivnyas invested in inventory. Her income is about 5,000 Grivnyas a month.

Marina is seeking a 12,500 Grivnya loan to increase her working capital and sales. Her small enterprise has been characterized by stable growth and development, and she doesn’t want to stop expanding her business, hoping to open one more vending location in the near future.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Eze

texts.en: M. makes shoe and bag to sell. He has been in this business for the past 7 years.  He is 42 years old and married with 4 children.  He is requesting for the loan amount of N50, 000 to purchase more materials for making shoes and bag. He says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more materials for making shoe and bag to sell.

loans.name: Agustina

texts.en:
Agustina L. is from Gango, city of Ozamis. She is 56 years old and married and has five adult children. To make a living, Agustina owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of products to the local community. She has been engaged in her business for five years and earns approximately $112 a month.

In April 2009, Agustina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Agustina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products for her retail store. This will be her second loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to puchase more products to sell

loans.name: Annet Nalubega‘S Group

texts.en:
Annet is a 62-year-old married woman with six children aged between 25 and 40 years. None of her children goes to school, but her grandchildren do. She owns a seven-roomed house where she resides with three people. Annet takes care of additional family members.The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.

Annet works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a stall selling bunches and clusters of bananas in Ntinda Kigowa Zone. Annet works seven days a week, selling both retail and wholesale. She receives an average of 20 customers a day. Her major business challenges include defaulters and the ever-increasing price of bananas due to persistent drought in banana-growing areas. Her monthly expenses include water and electricity bills, feeding the family, and transportation to and from Nakawa Market, where she buys bananas.

Annet has been in this business for over 28 years and with MCDT for 10 years, servicing her 23 loans working with the same group mates. Annet joined MCDT because it was near her home and also because of working in the group.She wants to use her part of this loan to buy more bunches of bananas. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more bananas for sale

loans.name: Ana Riza

texts.en: Rice farming is the way of living of Ana. She is 29 years old with two children, her eldest is 3 years old. She started her farming business in 2006. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to be able to support her business. Now she would like to request a loan of 15,000 Php to buy fertilizers and pay expenses in maintaining her rice field.

loans.use: Fertilizers and farm materials

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en: Rhoda is 50 years old, married with five children. Her husband works with the government and he also supports the home. Her children are excelling in school and they attend a government school. Rhoda sells melons and yams at wholesale and retail prices to her customers. Melon is used in Nigerian in the preparation of 'egusi' soup. The demand for her melons is high and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers.The machine besides her in the picture is used for breaking the melon. She is requesting a loan amount of NGN 100,000 as a loan to purchase more melons and yams to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more yams and melons to sell

loans.name: La Venta Group

texts.es:
El grupo la venta está integrado por tres mujeres trabajadoras muy capaces quienes aprovecharan estas fechas para seguir trabajando con la esperanza que el nuevo año sea mejor. 

Una de ellas es Juliana Canda H. quien comenzó con una pequeña venta ubicada en el kilómetro 17 carretera Masaya; pero por los altos costos que implicaba el alquiler la traslado a su domicilio. Aun con el traslado según Canda este año ha sido uno de los mejores de la venta. 

Aura Lila L. desde hace cuatro años vende ropa usada y con los créditos desde hace un año comercializa cosméticos de la marca Avon. Mientras María Magdalena R. en 2002 instalo una cerrajería en la cual trabaja junto con su esposo y este año nuevo si lo permite Dios desea remodelar su hogar.
texts.en:
The "La venta" group is made up of three hard-working and very capable women who take advantage of these dates to continue working with the hope that the new year will be better. One of them is Juliana Canda H. who began with a small shop located at kilometer 17 on the Masaya highway. Nevertheless, due to the high costs required with renting she moved to her home. Even with the move, according to Canda, this year has been one of the best for sales. For four years, Aura Lila Landex has sold used clothing and with the loans, she has sold Avon branded cosmetics for one year. Meanwhile, María Magdalena R. started a locksmiths business in 2002 where she works alongside her husband and, in this new year, as long as God permits it, she wishes to remodel her home.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase basic grains and other products.

loans.name: Jerónimo

texts.es:
Jerónimo pertenece al banco comunal “VIRGEN ASUNTA DE RACCHI” de la Asociación Arariwa.  El vive en el poblado de Rarcchí de la provincia de Urubamba del departamento del Cusco. Rarcchí esta a 45 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.
 
Jerónimo es agricultor y ganadero. El socio nos cuenta que se dedica a la crianza de animales como por ejemplo chanchos, gallinas y cuyes. El socio vende sus animales en las ferias agropecuarias. Jerónimo y su familia cosechan productos como papas, cebollas, zanahorias y muchas más. El socio requiere el préstamo para el gasto familiar y para comprar semillas.        

El socio se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Jerónimo is a member of Asociación Arariwa's “VIRGEN ASUNTA DE RACCHI” communal bank. He lives in Rarcchí, which is in Urubamba province, Cusco department. Rarcchí is 45 minutes away from Cusco. Jerónimo is a farmer and cattleman. He tells us that he raises animals like: pigs, chickens and guinea-pigs. He sells the animals at various livestock fairs. Jerónimo and his family also farm products like: potatoes, onions, carrots, and many others. He needs funding to meet household expenses and to buy seed. He is grateful for the opportunity offered by this means and pledges to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seed and to pay household expenses.

loans.name: Mary Ngure

texts.en:
Mary is an old lady of 70 years and widowed. She has four children who are in their 40‘s.

Mary was a dressmaker in Mombasa before she started running a retail shop nineteen years ago. She employs one person to assist her in her business. Mary also earns extra income from her rental houses.

Faulu Kenya has helped Mary manage her business and she now requests Kes 30,000 which she will use to buy a fridge for her business.

loans.use: To buy a fridge for her business

loans.name: Amor Y Amistad 2,3,4 Group

texts.en:
Tanis is the coordinator of her group, Amor y Amistad (Love and Friendship), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti) generally. Her group is located in the Samana peninsula, a lush, rugged area with a nascent tourism industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and three children.

Tania is excited to be taking her tenth loan  with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her beauty salon by purchasing a basin for washing hair as well as a line of hair products, including shampoo and straighteners. She will use the profits to invest in her children by purchasing food, shoes, pencils and backpacks for them. She would also like to purchase a vehicle. Finally, she would like to invest in her business by securing a locale for it that is in a high traffic area and which is big enough to accommodate an ice cream shop as well. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: to purchase a washing basin and hair products

loans.name: Yerlin Jose

texts.es: El Sr. Yerlin M. es originario del municipio de El Sauce, se desempeña como Guarda de Seguridad en la Alcaldía Municipal de El Sauce donde tiene año y medio de laborar. El crédito solicitado será invertido en la compra de medicinas con el objetivo de mejorar la salud de su mamá.
texts.en:
Yerlin M. is from El Sauce. He has been a security guard for the city of El Sauce for a year and a half. He is asking for funding to buy medicines to improve his mother's health.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay for for medical expenses.

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.es:
Julio Cesar M. F.,  Labora como Vigilante en el Teatro Nacional Rubén Darío de Managua, el tiene un hijo a su cargo,  y este  se encuentran en edad escolar, es casado, es su primer  crédito con CEPRODEL y este va hacer invertido en el mejoramiento de su casa de habitación, gracias al financiamiento otorgados por CEPRODEL.  
El crédito solicitado es para invertir en la compra de materiales de construcción  como: cemento, arena y piso para terminar de poner el piso en su casa de habitación.
 Todo esto con el objetivo de Brindarles mayor seguridad y  una mejor condición de vida a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Julio César M. F. works as a guard in Managua's Teatro Nacional Rubén Darío. He has one school-age son and is married. This is first loan from CEPRODEL, and he will invest it in improving his one-room house, thanks to the financing CEPRODEL provides. The requested loan will be used to purchase construction materials like cement, sand, and flooring so he can finish installing the floor in his home. The goal of all this is to offer his son a better, safer living environment.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Improving and expanding his home

loans.name: Carmencita

texts.en:
Carmencita M. is from the village of Marilucao, Gingoog City. She is 56 years old and married with two adult children. To make a living, she runs a retail store selling soft drinks including mineral water. Carmencita has had this business for over three years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Carmencita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Carmencita is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan she has taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Doung

texts.en:
Mrs. Doung S. is 39 years old and has been selling fresh fish in the busy local market for more than sixteen years. She sells fish that she gets from her husband’s fishing or buys from her wholesale supplier and other fishermen. She is married to Soun Sophan, 43, who fishes in and around the lakes of his community. The couple has seven children; five of whom attend school, while the remaining two help in their parent's business. They reside in a wooden house located along the river. 

Currently, the quantity of fish caught is declining due to their lack of fishing gear. That is why Doung S. has requested a loan in order to purchase more equipment for her husband to use when fishing.

loans.use: To purchase more equipment for her husband to use when fishing

loans.name: Prisca

texts.fr: Née en 1982 à Bohicon dans le département du Zou, B. Prisca vit depuis sept ans environs à Kindonou, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Prisca est mariée à TCHEHOUENOU François, un couturier, et est mère d’un enfant qui est scolarisé. Prisca vit ensemble avec son mari et son enfant. Le couple se partage les charges familiales. Prisca n’a pas été à l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Prisca vend des chaussures et aussi des tissus au marché de Kindonou à Cotonou. Prisca achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Prisca exerce cette activité depuis six ans et a obtenu une fois déjà un crédit  auprès de ALIDé. Prisca a bien effectué le remboursement de ce prêt. Dans le but d’agrandir son activité et de mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle, Prisca sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
Born in 1982 in Bohicon in the "département" of Zou, Prisca B. has lived for around seven years in Kindonou, a district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Prisca is married to François TCHEHOUENOU, a tailor, and is mother to one child who is at school. She lives with her husband and child. The couple shares responsibility for the family's expenses. Prisca did not go to school. In order to provide for her needs, she sells shoes and also fabrics at the Kindonou market in Cotonou. Prisca buys her products in Dantokpa, Benin's international market. She has been carrying out this activity for six years and has already had one loan from ALIDé. She repaid this loan without incident. With the aim of expanding her business and coping better with customer demand, Prisca is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of shoes and damask fabric

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty M. is from the village of Talic. She is 45 years old and is a widow. Betty owns and operates a business selling dried fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Betty joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 4th from PMPC. Betty plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Felicity Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Felicity is a lovely and hard-working woman. She is married to a commercial driver and together they have three children. She is now thirty-three years old. Felicity lives together with her family in a rented apartment at Sunyani, where she also has her business. She is able to provide support to her family’s financial needs through the sale of “banku”. Banku is one of the Ghanaian favorite local dishes that are rich in carbohydrates. It is prepared with corn dough and some amount of cassava dough, cooked between 1-2 hours and eaten with either palm nut or peanut soup. It can also be enjoyed with ground pepper and tomatoes and tilapia. Banku is known throughout all the tribes in Ghana and commonly sold in street stalls. 

Selling for the past 15 years, Felicity has made quite a number of faithful customers through good customer relations. She plans to invest the loan to purchase maize, meat, groundnuts and other food ingredients to improve her food quality.

Felicity is currently the leader of a trust bank group called 'Felicity', named after the leader and made up of nine members. The other members are also engaged in petty trading and food processing businesses.

loans.use: To purchase food ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Khady

texts.fr: Madame Khady G. est parent bénéficiaire, sociétaire  de la caisse de Ouakam depuis 7 ans. Elle a déjà rembourse 6 prêts  antérieurs. Elle évolue depuis 10 ans dans le commerce de Thiouraye, gâteau (elle a fait la pâtisserie), crème  glacée, et jus. C’est le souci d’aider son mari a supporter les charges familiales qui l’a incite a choisir cette activité. Elle a démarré  par la vente de gâteau  et de cacahuètes. Elle sollicite un crédit de 150 000 frs  prévu  pour l’achat d’une plus grande quantité  de produits qu’elle commercialise pour éviter  les ruptures.
texts.en:
Khady G. has been a parent member of the Ouakam credit institution for seven years. She already repaid six previous loans. She has been running her business for over ten years; she sells thiouraye (traditional body essence), cakes that she bakes herself, ice cream and juices. She would like to help her husband with the family expenses; for this reason she started this business and she began by selling cakes and peanuts. She is requesting a loan of 150,000 francs in order to purchase a larger quantity of products and avoid market disruptions.

Translated from French by Monica Urban, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to increase stock

loans.name: Merly

texts.en: Merly A. is from the village of Lower Tambo, Macasandig, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 33 years old. Merly is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Merly runs a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes from serving roasted pork and chicken meat in the local community. Merly has been engaged in her business for less than a year and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. In 2010, Merly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merly is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This will be the first loan taken out by Merly from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.
